msContents.summary: The oldest surviving copy of Bede’s Commentary on the Old Testament Book of Proverbs, produced in his own monastery of Wearmouth-Jarrow.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Commentary on Proverbs

listBibl.bibl: ed. Beda Venerabilis : In prouerbia salomonis libri III, CCSL 119B (1983).

note.p: Text is acephalous and incomplete. The first and most of the second quire has been lost, containing all of Lib 1, ch. 1 and the first third of ch. 2. A bifolium and a singleton survive from the second quire but have been rearranged. The text begins on fol. 2r at I.ii.69 (‘mansuetudinis, rectus per cautelam discretionis…’).Text lost after fol. 3v which ends at I.ii.144 (‘sed eos qui hoc temporemortui pro enormitate flagiti[orum]’). Resumes at fol. 1r (end of I.ii.180;‘…et eorum qui hominibus boni uidentur’). Text lost between fol. 1v and fol. 4r, from i.iii.22 (after ‘Sit ergo uirtus misericordiae et ueritatis radici infixa mentis,promatur et uoce…’) to i.iii.58 (from ‘In ossibus solida…’).
Text lost after fol. 24, one leaf missing (I.viii.25-59).
Wanting a quire (a quaternion) between fol. 42v (which ends at II.xiii.21;‘Pauper e contra…’) and fol. 43r (which begins at II.xv.8; ‘aut historicatantum ratione scripta…’).
Text lost after fol. 55, one leaf missing (II.xix.15-52)
Text lost after fol. 108, one leaf missing (III.xxxi.206-244)

The final quire is missing a bifolium with text lacking before fol. 112 (III.xxxi.355-393) and after fol. 115 (the final lines of the text, III.xxxi.549-587, after ‘ubi autem sine fide quae per dilectionem operatur fiunt nihil agentibus...’).

msItem.note: Glossed in Latin by Aldred, the Old English glossator of the Lindisfarne Gospels (London, British Library, Cotton MS Nero D IV), presumably at Chester-le-Street in the tenth century.

supportDesc.collation:
[quire missing]; 1(probably 8-5, with leaves 1-3, 6 and 8 missing with loss of text; the surviving leaves are the central bifolium, now fols. 2-3 and the 7th leaf, now fol. 1) (fols.1–3), 2–3(8) (fols. 4–19), 4(8-1, 6th leaf missing with loss of text) (fols. 20–26), 5–6(8) (fols. 27-42), [quire missing], 7(8) (fols. 43–50), 8(8-1, 6th leaf missing with loss of text) (fols. 51–57), 9–10(8) (fols. 58–73), 11(8–2+1, first two original leaves replaced in the 12th century by fol. 74) (fols. 74–80), 12–14(8) (fols. 81–104), 15(8-1, 5th leaf missing with loss of text) (fols. 105–111), 16(6-2, missing 1st and 6th leaves with loss of text) (fols. 112–115).
Original quire marks (III–XVI, missing VIII, X, and XIII) were Roman numerals centralised in the lower margin of the last page of each gathering and surrounded by vines. Many of these have since been erased and the quires renumbered II–XVI.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 column, ruled in dry point for 22 long lines. Ruled space 200–210 148

handDesc.handNote: Text of Bede’s Commentary written by a single hand in insular minuscule script. Notable is the form of p, the bow of which is open and terminates in a flick causing it to somewhat resemble an R.

Biblical lemma written by the same hand in uncial script. Closely comparable to other examples of uncial from Wearmouth-Jarrow, the Northumbrian monastery where Bede spent his life. It particularly resembles the capitula type of uncial used in bibles produced in that scriptorium (CLA 2.235).

decoDesc.decoNote: Good initials. (Pächt and Alexander iii. 8, pl. I). Initials in the black ink of the text mark the beginning of Book 2 (fol. 29r) and Book 3 (fol. 79v) of the Commentary and are decorated with curling or interlacing scrolls from which sprout ivy leaves.

binding.p: Leather binding over pasteboards, c. 1600. The presence of Cope’s number on a flyleaf suggests that the binding was on the manuscript in his time (see Watson, ‘The Manuscript Collection of Sir Walter Cope (d. 1614)’, 1987, p. 296).

history.provenance: Glossed in Latin by Aldred, the Old English glossator of the Lindisfarne Gospels (London, British Library, Cotton MS Nero D IV), presumably at Chester-le-Street, Durham in the tenth century (see In the Beginning: Bibles Before the Year 1000, 2006, no. 56, pp. 294–5 [Bruce Barker-Benfield]).

Durham, Benedictine cathedral priory of St Cuthbert: London, British Library, Harley MS 4688 was copied from MS Bodley 819 in Durham, s. xii, and the punctuation and abbreviations of the latter were modified to allow this (ibid.).
history.acquisition: Presented by sir Walter Cope in 1602; '22' on fol. vii verso is probably a Cope number, cf. Watson, pp. 269-70.

Decoration, localization, and date follow R. Gameson, ‘Writing at Wearmouth Jarrow’ in C. Breay and J. Story (eds) Manuscripts in the Anglo-Saxon Kingdoms: Cultures and Connections (London, 2021), pp. 28–44. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue (1922).
